metadata.title: Coronavirus: What’s at stake for developing countries? | by Ali Raza | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Coronavirus: What’s at stake for developing countries?
metadata.description: Estimates the rising number of coronavirus cases in Pakistan, discusses if Pakistan's healthcare system can handle it, lists frequently asked questions, and lists what Pakistanis can do to avoid an outbreak.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: State of health sector in Pakistan
Coronavirus: act today or people will die
How to protect yourself from coronavirus
Coronavirus is airborne doesn’t mean doomed
Not all hand sanitisers work against coronavirus
Coronavirus Looks less deadly than before but still not like flu
Dispensaries and beds by Province in Pakistan
Lower deaths rates provide a glimmer of hope

all_paragraphs: Note: This article doesn’t predict the number of cases of coronavirus in Pakistan, and thus, shouldn’t serve as a source of panic. Rather, the article estimates the no. of cases in specific circumstances, if and only if those circumstances occur, in an effort to emphasise the importance of timely prevention measures.

A lot has been happening in the world because of the coronavirus in recent weeks. With death tolls rising and borders being shut, what can developing countries like Pakistan learn from other countries before it gets worse for them?

Taking into account Pakistan’s dynamics and demographics I will try to estimate the potential risk to Pakistan based on some of the badly hit countries in the world in an effort to highlight how important it is to start taking it seriously. Here is what I am going to cover in this article:
Note: Numbers are likely to change after the article has been published.

The coronavirus COVID-19 has already spread to more than 176 countries¹ and territories around the world at the time of writing. While, a few countries like China and South Korea seem to have contained the virus as the no. of new cases are decreasing rapidly, in other parts of the world, it has just started growing exponentially.

With more than 221,926 confirmed cases and 8,999 deaths, governments have been forced to shut down borders, markets, schools, institutions, and take many other drastic measures in an attempt to contain the virus.
Let’s start by briefly taking a look at some charts related to the spread of virus in China, South Korea, Europe, and the USA.
Following chart shows the no. of confirmed cases in some of the most affected countries in the world.

Due to drastic measures taken by China, new cases there finally seem to decline in numbers but the situation is getting exponentially worse in Europe and USA. Let’s zoom into that part of the chart. Here is the chart for countries excluding china:

Fatality rates really differ across different regions and countries because of many factors at play but the latest studies¹⁴ have estimated the worldwide rate to be 1.4%, significantly less than previously estimated 2–3%.
Here is the chart for fatalities across different countries:
Zooming into the exponentially increasing curves gives us the following chart:

All the charts in this section should provide you with enough clue of how exponentially the virus is spreading among populations and that it seems to be just the start of a catastrophic situation for many of the countries.

Even if the whole world halts immediately, new cases would keep appearing exponentially for at least another 5-14 days¹, as that’s the incubation period of the virus, worsening the situation for the healthcare systems and infrastructure.
Bad news: No. of infections can possibly go much (really really much ) higher in major cities of Pakistan compared to many of the other countries.
Good news: Death rate (as % of confirmed cases) would probably be much less in Pakistan.

It’s really difficult to predict the no. of infections and deaths in Pakistan based on the limited data so far, in fact, any prediction would be no more than speculation at this time, possibly resulting in panic.

However, instead of predicting the no. of infections, we can attempt to apply the data and situation from other countries where virus has spread exponentially, to Pakistan’s demographics and try to estimate the numbers for Pakistan, only if things took a turn for the worse.
I will take Germany’s case as an example because it:
The high population density in major cities of Pakistan and higher average social circle can help in the spread of virus while less number of international visitors should have the opposite effect.
It’s pretty intuitive to assume that population density has at least some sort of connection with the rate of increase of cases but this needs to be validated based on data.
One trick is to project the cumulative no. of cases for some of the countries relative to their population densities with China and see if they become similar, as their pop. densities become similar.
³Chart on the left shows the population density of Wuhan (majorly hit city in China), Germany, and Italy.
We want to see how the rise of coronavirus cases in Germany and Italy look like if their population densities approach Wuhan’s population density.

I scaled the curve of no. of coronavirus cases for Germany and Italy as a ratio of their population density with Wuhan, and as their population densities approach to Wuhan’s, the curves become very similar.
Figure 6 below explains this behaviour. Curves have also been time shifted for easy comparison.
Note: For simplicity’s sake and because the major regions in each country have the majority of the infections, curves for individual regions are not used.

It shows that the rate of increase of infections become very similar for different countries if they have similar population densities. But this happens only after cases reach a certain threshold (because the curves needed to be time shifted).
This threshold is different for each country and region (seen in Figure 7 below). For the rest of this article, we will call this threshold as infection threshold.
After a certain no. of infections have been confirmed, (exponential) rise of cases is similar across different countries.
The higher the population density, faster the spread of virus

It’s important to understand that Experiment doesn’t necessarily mean that the rise of infections is directly proportional to the population density with the same factor because there are possibly so many other factors involved.
Any estimations based on relative population densities of two countries can possibly only show how many cases could there be in a country based on another, if it starts having similar circumstances.

As mentioned in the previous section, predicting a country’s coronavirus cases is not effectively possible as there are so many unknown factors and this article doesn’t intend to incite panic by speculating.

Therefore, I will be using Germany’s rate of spread of virus to find possible no. of infections in major cities of Pakistan based on their relative population densities with Germany (after no. of cases exceed a threshold). This effectively means that:

If situation like Germany starts happening in Pakistan and no. of cases in Karachi, Lahore, and Rawalpindi surpass a certain threshold, we can easily approach the no. of coronavirus cases estimated in this section, unless otherwise, preventive measure are taken in advance.
Let’s start by comparing the population density of Karachi, Lahore, and Rawalpindi (3 major cities in Pakistan) with respect to other regions/countries.
A very high population density in Karachi and Lahore can be an easy playground for coronavirus, possibly resulting in a very high no. of infections in a very short amount of time.

Following chart shows the estimated rise in number of infections for Karachi, Lahore, and Rawalpindi, after they exceed 159 infections (infection threshold for three Pakistani cities) within each city and if circumstances like Germany happen in Pakistan.

Relative population density factor with Germany’s density for Karachi, Lahore, and Rawalpindi was taken from Figure 7 and then multiplied with Germany’s curve of rise in infections from Figure 6 to estimate rise of infections for Karachi, Lahore, and Rawalpindi, respectively.
Above chart shows a potentially catastrophic situation for highly populated regions of Pakistan if the spread of the virus is not contained at early stages.

If preventive measures are not taken already, no. of cases in Karachi surpass 159, and virus spreads like it has been spreading in Germany, then Karachi can possibly have more than half a million infected people in just another 14 to 16 days.

Hopefully, it never happens because seemingly the Government of Pakistan has already started taking several measures in an attempt to contain the virus. But if and when it does happen, then the picture is a really bleak one for Pakistan.
Pakistan has one of the youngest population in the world which should probably result in a much lower death rate (as % of confirmed + opened cases)

We don’t have very accurate death rates for coronavirus yet because the pandemic is still ongoing and there are many unresolved infection cases. It also really depends on the region and country, between 0.6% in South Korea and 4.4% in Iran which one should we use?¹
For this case study, world’s average fatality rate across different age groups should suffice.
As an example, let’s compare the population age groups of Pakistan² and Italy⁴ along with worldwide coronavirus fatality rates.

Figure 8 shows a relatively positive picture for Pakistan. Pakistan’s population (teal coloured bars) is much younger than Italy’s Population (orange-red coloured bars) and estimates suggest a much higher fatality rate among older populations¹. Fatality rates (red coloured bars) for the age group can be seen as white text in the middle of y axis.
Coronavirus fatality rate in Pakistan is estimated to be relatively lower than the rest of world (if patients are treated properly).
For instance, fatality rate in Pakistan should be at least 4 times lesser than that of Italy, in theory.
Based on the demographics of Pakistan and fatality rates of coronavirus across age groups, let’s estimate the no. of fatalities from the estimated no. of infections presented in Figure 8.

Even with a much smaller fatality rate, we are looking at very high no. of deaths because of the much higher no. of infections. Hence it’s of utmost importance to limit the number of infections as much as possible in major cities of Pakistan.
With one of the lowest Public Health Expenditure as % of GDP in the world, Pakistan has only 0.6 beds per 1000 people⁵. For comparison, Germany has 8.5 beds per 1000 people.

The situation is especially bad in major cities, like Karachi, where the population is a staggering 14.91 million. How long the spread of infection can go before the city’s health infrastructure falls into chaos? Let me show you again through some charts.
Here is the chart showing available hospital beds across Pakistan.

For a city with a population of 14.91 million (i.e Karachi) and an estimated 500k+ infections in just over 14 days, even all of the 130k+ hospital beds in Pakistan cannot handle such a big number of patients.
Of course, not all the patients with virus need to be hospitalised, so we should take that into account for our estimations.
The chart on the left by American Hospital Association⁶ shows the estimated percentage of severe and critical patients having coronavirus who need to be hospitalised.
For simplicity’s sake, we will treat severe and critical cases as same, as that should be enough to prove the point.
Using the estimated number of infections for Karachi from Figure 8 and the estimate that 18.5% of patients need to be hospitalised out of all the patients, we can come up with the following chart:
Even if all of Province’s hospital beds are already free, estimated no. of patients from Karachi who need to be hospitalised would exhaust the whole Province’s capacity in just under 12 days.

It is no brainer that if the situation depicted in this section for the major cities start happening in Pakistan, it’s only a matter of a couple of weeks before the healthcare system of Pakistan crumbles into chaos, thus, resulting in even further spread.

Also, the estimations were done based on Germany’s circumstances, which is not even the worst hit among all the countries by coronavirus. Estimations based on Italy’s circumstances are going to be even worse, where the virus has spread much quicker than in Germany.
Yes, although difficult, it is in fact avoidable and possible to contain as already demonstrated in China.

Latest figures show 189 confirmed cases in Pakistan. With a possibly underreported number of cases because of lack of health facilities as well as lack of no. of doctors, ground reality might be already worse than being reported and only become visible if and when a large number of fatalities start happening, but by that stage, it will probably be too late.

In any case, it’s not too late for Pakistan yet. If enough measures on government level are taken and people take their individual and social responsibilities seriously, then it is very possible to contain it
If not, then just wait for it to hit you really hard.
It’s not the main purpose of the article to list all of the precautionary measures and steps people can take, but here is a short list with most important ones:
Most of the studies say no⁸.
Some new studies say yes but only for a short amount of time. So as long as you stay 2–3 feet away from infected, it’s probably not a concern.
⁹Washing hands is your best chance. But alcohol-based hand sanitisers (with > 60% alcohol) are a practical alternative when soap and water aren’t available.
⁷Better than not having anything but not very effective as virus can penetrate the mask and even also spread through eyes.
— Is the coronavirus just like flu, but overhyped?
¹⁰Totally not, coronavirus is at least 10 times and up to 30 times deadlier than flu.

Note from the editors: Towards Data Science is a Medium publication primarily based on the study of data science and machine learning. We are not health professionals or epidemiologists, and the opinions of this article should not be interpreted as professional advice. To learn more about the coronavirus pandemic, you can click here.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Machine Learning Engineer at Revolut, Berlin
